Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Nested routers do not produce external urls and are not navigable to without clicking" (#1816) at vuejs/vue-router
Events.RelatedBody:
### Version
3.0.1

### Reproduction link
[https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/tree/dev/examples/nested-router](https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/tree/dev/examples/nested-router)

### Steps to reproduce
In a clone of vue-router:
- npm run dev
- open http://localhost:8080/nested-router/
- Click nested-router
- Hover over the nested foo link
- Copy that link and try it in a new browser window
- Click the nested foo link and look at the browser address bar - it does not change.


### What is expected?
The url for the nested foo should be 
http://localhost:8080/nested-router/nested-router/bar

This should work in a new browser. 


### What is actually happening?
The url for the nested foo is actually
http://localhost:8080/bar, which is in the parent directory of the example.

This obviously does not work in a new browser.

---
This appears externally just like changing a component based on internal data, even though the route mechanism is used.
I thought this would be useful for modularity of components. It appears only a global flat list of routes works well currently.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nested routers don't have externally usable urls, and do not change the browser address bar when used. " (#1815) at vuejs/vue-router
Events.RelatedBody:
<!--
IMPORTANT: Please use the following link to create a new issue:

  https://new-issue.vuejs.org/?repo=vuejs/vue-router

If your issue was not created using the app above, it will be closed immediately.
-->

In the nested-router example, the urls on the nested router links are immediately under the root. 
Eg on the dev server:
http://localhost:8080/bar, which is in the parent directory of the example. 
You would expect it to be: 
http://localhost:8080/nested-router/nested-router/bar 
The first nested-router path segment is the directory, the second is a page internal route. Slightly confusing because its in history mode. 

If this expected url is used in the address bar, that doesn't work. When the links are clicked, the target component is displayed. But the browser address stays at the url of the component:
http://localhost:8080/nested-router/nested-router

So overall this appears externally just like changing a component based on internal data, even though the route mechanism is used.
